In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

Below is an example of how you can write a function in Julia named `wrap_string` that takes a single string input and a maximum text width (`text_width`), then efficiently wraps the text to a new line whenever adding another word would exceed the specified `text_width`. This implementation makes sure that individual lines do not exceed the text width limit unless a single word itself is longer than the `text_width`.

```julia
function wrap_string(text::String, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    current_line_length = 0
    result = ""
    
    for word in words
        if current_line_length + length(word) + (current_line_length > 0 ? 1 : 0) > text_width
            result *= "\n"
            current_line_length = 0
        end
        if current_line_length > 0
            result *= " "
            current_line_length += 1  # for space
        end
        result *= word
        current_line_length += length(word)
    end
    
    return result
end
```

### Example Usage

Here is how you might use this function:
```julia
text = "Julia is a high-level, high-performance dynamic programming language for technical computing."
wrapped_text = wrap_string(text, 15)
print(wrapped_text)
```
This should output something like:
```
Julia is a
high-level,
high-performance
dynamic
programming
language for
technical
computing.
```

This example wraps the given text where the maximum width of any line does not exceed 15 characters. Words themselves are not broken apart; the function simply moves entire words to the next line when adding another word would exceed the maximum width. Adjust the `text_width` value based on your needs to see different wrapping behaviors.
